questions.text: A 40-year-old woman reports experiencing recurrent headaches that last between 6 and 48 hours. She often feels fatigued and has mood changes before the headaches begin. According to the International Headache Society's criteria, which features are essential for diagnosing her condition as migraine?

choices.text: Unilateral pain with photophobia without nausea
Bilateral pain with photophobia and nausea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Unilateral throbbing pain with phonophobia

Explanation:

Unilateral throbbing pain with phonophobia meets the diagnostic criteria for migraines. It specifies unilateral pain, describes the pain as throbbing (a key characteristic), and includes phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), fulfilling the requirement for at least three features from the specified list.

Diagnostic Classification:

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

At least 2 of the following features:

Plus at least 1 of the following features:
  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

 

Bilateral pricking pain with nausea (Option A): This describes bilateral pain, which does not meet migraine criteria that require unilateral pain. The term "pricking" suggests a tension-type headache rather than a migraine.

 

Unilateral pain with photophobia without nausea (Option B): This option includes unilateral pain and photophobia, but lacks nausea. Without two qualifying features, it cannot be fully classified as migraine.

 

Bilateral pain with photophobia and nausea (Option D): Although it includes photophobia and nausea, bilateral pain contradicts migraine criteria, which require unilateral pain. Thus, it cannot be classified as a migraine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 9-month history of frequent headaches occurring at least 3 times per week. She describes the pain as a dull, bilateral ache that feels like a tight band around her head. The headaches are often accompanied by neck tension, stress, and fatigue. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Amitriptyline, starting at 20 mg daily, with gradual increases as needed.
Combination of Ibuprofen 400 mg plus acetaminophen 1000 mg.
Aspirin and Botulinum toxin type A inejctions
Combination of massage therapy and acupuncture

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amitriptyline, starting at 20 mg daily, with gradual increases as needed.

Explanation:

  • This patient likely has chronic tension-type headache (TTH), given her 9-month history of frequent headaches (at least 3 times per week).
  • The pain is described as a dull, bilateral ache, often associated with neck tension, stress, and fatigue, which are characteristic features of TTH.
  • Her report of difficulty concentrating and disrupted sleep further supports the chronic nature of the headaches, distinguishing them from episodic TTH.
  • Amitriptyline is the first-line treatment for chronic tension-type headaches (TTH). It is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) used for prevention, and it should be started at a low dose (10–25 mg daily) and increased gradually.

 

Treatment of Tension-Type Headache (TTH)

1. Episodic TTH

  • First-line Drugs:
    • Ibuprofen: 400 mg
    • Acetaminophen: 1000 mg
    • Combination: Ibuprofen and acetaminophen together may provide better results. (Option B ruled out)
  • Other NSAIDs (effective for acute TTH):
    • Naproxen sodium: 375–550 mg
    • Ketoprofen: 25–50 mg
    • Diclofenac: 50–100 mg
  • Not Recommended:
    • Aspirin (ASA): 500 mg dose found to be no more effective than placebo. (Option C ruled out)
  • Precaution:
    • Avoid frequent analgesic use to prevent medication-overuse headaches.

2. Chronic TTH

  • Pharmacological Management:
    • Amitriptyline (TCA): Primary drug for chronic TTH prevention
      • Start at 10–25 mg daily; increase by 10–25 mg weekly as needed.
      • Continue for at least 6 months, then consider tapering.
      • Adverse effects: dry mouth, drowsiness, urinary retention, cardiac arrhythmias, glaucoma.
    • SSRIs and SNRIs: Generally less effective than TCAs.
    • Botulinum toxin type A: Not first-line; may be considered in refractory cases. (Option C ruled out)
  • Non-Pharmacological Management:
    • Physical therapy: Includes relaxation, exercise, and posture improvement.
    • Biofeedback and Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
    • Additional therapies (may help in acute or chronic TTH): (Option D ruled out)
      • Massage, manipulation, acupuncture, osteopathic manipulation

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with recurrent, sharp, electric shock-like pain on the right side of her face, affecting her jaw and cheek. The pain is triggered by light touch, such as brushing her teeth or shaving. She reports these episodes happening multiple times a day and lasting only a few seconds. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding her condition?

choices.text: The most likely diagnosis is glossopharyngeal neuralgia, as the pain is localized to the jaw and oral cavity and is triggered by chewing.
Most commonly caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve, often by the superior cerebellar artery.
The primary treatment is surgical decompression of the glossopharyngeal nerve.
This patient's condition is most likely to involve the ophthalmic branch (V1) of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Most commonly caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve, often by the superior cerebellar artery.

Explanation:

This patient has trigeminal neuralgia (TN), characterized by sharp, electric shock-like pain affecting the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches of the trigeminal nerve, triggered by light touch. The condition is most commonly caused by vascular compression, often by the superior cerebellar artery, leading to demyelination of the nerve.

Aspect

Trigeminal Neuralgia

Glossopharyngeal Neuralgia

About
  • Also known as "tic douloureux," is a chronic neurological condition marked by recurrent, brief episodes of electric shock-like facial pain.
  • Usually affects one side of the face and commonly involves the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Pain episodes are triggered by stimuli like touch, chewing, or exposure to cold air.
  • A rare pain syndrome affecting the sensory distribution of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
  • Characterized by brief, sharp, unilateral pain in areas like the jaw angle, ear, tonsillar fossa, and base of the tongue.
  • Pain episodes are triggered by coughing, talking, or swallowing. (Option A ruled out)

Etiopathogenesis
  • Caused mainly by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve root, ofte,pn by the superior cerebellar artery.
  • Other causes include space-occupying lesions (e.g., tumors), multiple sclerosis, or other vascular abnormalities.
  • Compression leads to demyelination of the nerve, resulting in abnormal transmission of impulses, causing pain.
  • Idiopathic (unknown cause) or secondary to specific conditions:
  • Vascular compression, especially near the nerve root.
  • Demyelinating diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis), infections, and autoimmune conditions (e.g., Sjögren's disease).
  • Intracranial tumors (medullary tumors, CP angle tumors).
  • Anatomical anomalies (Eagle syndrome).
  • Rarely linked with oropharyngeal cancers (e.g., tongue carcinoma).

Clinical Features
  • Pain is typically unilateral, sharp, and brief, often described as "electric shock-like."
  • Triggers include light touch to specific facial areas ("trigger zones") and routine activities like brushing teeth or shaving.
  • Pain episodes can occur multiple times per day, sometimes with a refractory period following each episode.
  • V1 involvement (rare) may present with autonomic symptoms like tearing and rhinorrhea. (Option D ruled out)
  • Intense, episodic, sharp pain lasting seconds to minutes.
  • Pain is unilateral, often affecting the ear, tongue base, and tonsillar fossa.
  • Relapsing-remitting pain pattern, may lead to weight loss due to difficulty eating.
  • Occasionally, pain is associated with bradycardia, asystole, or syncope.

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is often clinical, supported by MRI or MRA to rule out secondary causes or vascular compression.
  • High-resolution MRI (e.g., FIESTA sequencing) helps visualize nerve compression.
  • Diagnosis based on the International Classification of Headache Disorders criteria includes unilateral pain lasting seconds to minutes, triggered by innocuous stimuli, and of severe intensity.
  • Clinical diagnosis with history and exam.
  • Imaging:
  • MRI: Preferred to identify nerve compression by blood vessels or tumors.
  • MRA: To detect vascular compression.
  • CT and X-ray: Useful for detecting an elongated or calcified styloid process in Eagle syndrome.
  • Cardiac evaluation for syncopal cases: Echocardiogram and Holter monitoring.

Treatment
  • Pharmacologic Therapy:
    • First-line: Carbamazepine (FDA-approved) or oxcarbazepine; both may cause dizziness, hyponatremia, and other side effects. (Option C ruled out)
    • Second-line: Gabapentin, clonazepam, lamotrigine, and baclofen; used if first-line agents are ineffective.
  • Surgical Therapy:
    • Microvascular decompression: Effective in >90% of cases; involves craniotomy and vessel decompression.
    • Rhizotomy: Ablative procedures like thermocoagulation or chemical injection of the trigeminal nerve for pain relief.
    • Peripheral neurectomy: Performed on trigeminal branches in remote areas; moderate success with some recurrence.
  • Other Therapies:
    • Botulinum toxin injections: Provides relief in cases refractory to medications.
    • Deep brain stimulation: Used as a last-resort option in refractory cases, with limited evidence of effectiveness.
  • Medications: Carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine are first-line; other options include gabapentin, duloxetine, and pregabalin.
  • Nerve Blocks: Glossopharyngeal nerve block with anesthetics or radiofrequency ablation for persistent pain.
  • Surgery: Microvascular decompression is the main surgery for vascular compression; other procedures include rhizotomy or stylectomy for Eagle syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Naratriptan
			
			
			a) 5-HT1F Agonist
			
		
		
			
			2. Lasmiditan
			
			
			b) Dopamine Receptor Antagonist
			
		
		
			
			3. Rimegepant
			
			
			c) 5-HT1B/1D Agonist
			
		
		
			
			4. Prochlorperazine
			
			
			d) CGRP Receptor Antagonist
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

Explanation:

  • Triptans (5-HT1B/1D Agonists): Sumatriptan, rizatriptan, naratriptan, eletriptan, frovatriptan, zolmitriptan.
  • Gepants (CGRP Receptor Antagonists): Rimegepant, ubrogepant.
  • Ditans (5-HT1F Agonists): Lasmiditan.
  • Dopamine Receptor Antagonists: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine.

questions.text: A patient with left sided facial paralysis and arm weakness for the last eight hours. BP on admission is 160/100 mm Hg. Her CT head is normal. What is the next step in managment of this patient?

choices.text: Monitor Blood pressure and neurology consult

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A: Monitor Blood pressure and neurology consult

Explanation:

Patient with sudden onset neurological deficit and nornal CT scan can either be acute ischemic stroke or TIA event. Since BP is not falling into hypertensive crisis range monitoring of BP is required. The patient is out of window period for thrombolysis which is 4.5 hours with upper limit of 6 hours. The neurologist will order a CTA or DW-MRI based on facility availiable to further asses the patient. 

Drugs like Nicardipine or labetatol are FDA approved to lower BP is it is > 185/110 mm Hg and patient is a candidate for thrombolysis ( this is not the scenario given in the question).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent headaches. After a thorough evaluation, he is diagnosed with a headache that has a stinging character and characterized by the following features:
Duration: 5-240 seconds
Attacks: 3-200 attacks per day.
Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IV Lidocaine

Explanation:
The patient in question presents with a type of headache characterized by a duration of 5-240 seconds and a frequency of 3-200 attacks per day. These features align with SUNCT (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing).

  • Duration: SUNCT headaches are very brief, lasting from just a few seconds to a few minutes, often ranging between 5 to 240 seconds.
  • Frequency: The frequency of attacks is notably high, with patients experiencing anywhere from 3 to 200 attacks in a single day. This is a hallmark of SUNCT, distinguishing it from other headache types like Cluster Headaches, which typically involve fewer attacks per day (1-8).
  • Pain Quality: The pain associated with SUNCT is unilateral and can be described as sharp or stabbing, similar to the pain experienced in Cluster Headaches but significantly shorter in duration.

Intravenous Lidocaine has been shown to provide significant relief from the symptoms of SUNCT. The mechanism involves its action as a sodium channel blocker, which helps alleviate headache symptoms.

 

High-flow oxygen (Option A) This treatment is effective for Cluster Headaches, as inhaling high-flow oxygen can significantly decrease the severity of the pain. However, it is not indicated for SUNCT, where the duration and frequency of attacks are much different.

 

Sumatriptan (Option B) Triptans, such as Sumatriptan, are typically used for the acute treatment of Cluster Headaches and are effective for relieving pain when used at the onset of an attack. However, they are not the first-line treatment for SUNCT and are generally less effective for this condition.

 

Verapamil (Option D) While preventive medications such as verapamil are commonly used for Cluster Headaches to reduce the frequency of attacks, they do not specifically address acute SUNCT episodes and are not the preferred initial treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of new-onset headaches, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication. She also reports significant fatigue and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Refer for imaging studies of the carotid arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Start high-dose corticosteroids

Explanation:

  • Starting high-dose corticosteroids is the most appropriate next step in the management of Giant Cell Arteritis. Prompt initiation of high-dose corticosteroids is crucial to prevent complications, particularly vision loss, which can occur if the condition progresses.

Giant Cell Arteritis:

  • Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is a systemic vasculitis primarily affecting large and medium-sized arteries, particularly the temporal arteries. More prevalent in women than men (2-3 times more common).
  • Clinical features:
    • Presenting symptoms include new-onset headaches, often severe and localized to the temporal region, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, characterized by pain or fatigue in the jaw muscles during chewing.
    • Additionally, visual disturbances such as diplopia, blurred vision, or sudden vision loss may occur due to ischemic optic neuropathy.
    • Systemic symptoms like fatigue, fever, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss further characterize the condition.
  • Investigations:
    • Laboratory tests typically show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP).
    • Temporal artery biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test, showing necrotizing vasculitis and giant cells in the arterial wall.
  • Treatment: The management of GCA primarily involves the use of corticosteroids. High-dose corticosteroids, such as prednisone, are the mainstay of treatment

 

Perform temporal artery biopsy (Option B): While a temporal artery biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and is often performed, it should ideally be done after the initiation of corticosteroids if the diagnosis of GCA is highly suspected, especially considering the risk of blindness.

 

Initiate aspirin therapy (Option C): Aspirin may be considered for vascular protection, but it is not the primary treatment for GCA. The immediate focus should be on controlling inflammation with corticosteroids.

 

Refer for imaging studies of the carotid arteries (Option D) While imaging can be helpful in assessing the extent of vascular involvement, it is not the immediate step when GCA is suspected. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are sufficient to start treatment.

questions.text:
Match the variants of Migraine in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
			
			
			A. Associated with blindness and scintillating scotomas
			
		
		
			
			2. Cluster Headaches
			
			
			B. Retro-orbital pain in males
			
		
		
			
			3. Retinal Migraine
			
			
			C. Associated with occulomotor palsy
			
		
		
			
			4. Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
			
			
			D. Presents with hemiplegia and can be confused with stroke
			
		
		
			 
			
			E. Diagnosis often involves neuroimaging to rule out cerebrovascular accidents
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

Explanation:

Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine can present with neurological deficits, such as third nerve palsy, which may include symptoms like ptosis and squinting.
  • It typically causes severe pain that can lead to vision impairment

Cluster Headaches
  • Cluster headaches are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain.
  • They are more common in males and can be associated with other symptoms such as nasal congestion and watering of the eyes.

Retinal Migraine
  • Associated with transient vision loss or blindness due to vasospasm of the retinal arteries.
  • Symptoms such as scintillating scotomas are also present.

Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
  • Rare type of migraine that includes hemiplegia (temporary paralysis on one side of the body) as a symptom.
  • Because of this, it can easily be confused with a stroke.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of chronic migraines visits his physician to discuss treatment options. He is interested in triptans but has some health concerns that he wants to clarify. Which of the following is NOT a contraindication for triptans based on the provided information?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) History of seasonal allergies

Explanation:

Seasonal allergies do not affect the safety or efficacy of triptans and do not pose a risk in the context of migraine treatment. 

  • History of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, uncontrolled hypertension, and peripheral vascular disease as it can trigger vasospasm ( option A ruled out) 
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome and other cardiac conduction disorders due to sympathomimetic action that can trigger fast conduction via bundle of kent (Option C ruled out)
  • Concurrent use with ergot alkaloids or MAO inhibitors as it increases risk of serotonin syndrome and impairs triptan metabolism. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman completes the MIDAS questionnaire during her follow-up for chronic migraines. Her headaches have significantly impacted her work and social life. What is the primary purpose of the MIDAS assessment?

choices.text: To determine the specific medication needed for treatment.
To assess the frequency of headache attacks.
To evaluate headache-related disability and its impact on daily activities.
To classify the type of headache.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To evaluate headache-related disability and its impact on daily activities.

Explanation:

The MIDAS questionnaire specifically measures how migraines affect a person's productivity in work, school, and social activities, providing insights into their overall disability.

MIDAS Test:

  • The MIDAS (Migraine Disability Assessment) is a self-administered questionnaire.
  • It assesses headache-related disability over the past three months.
  • The questionnaire consists of five questions about productivity loss and limitations in work, school, household, and social activities.
  • It includes a global question on migraine severity, rated from 0 (no pain) to 10 (very severe pain).
  • Additional questions gather information on headache frequency and intensity.
  • The MIDAS is a reliable and valid tool with good test-retest reliability and correlates with clinical needs for medical care.

MIDAS Questionnaire

Instructions

Please answer the following questions about all the headaches you have had over the last 3 months.

Select your answer in the box next to each question. Select zero if you did not have the activity in the last 3 months. Please take the complete form to your healthcare professional.

Questions
  1. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss work or school because of your headaches?
  2. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity at work or school reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 1 where you missed work or school)?
  3. How many days in the last 3 months have you not done household work because of your headaches?
  4. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity in household work reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 3 where you did not do household work)?
  5. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss family, social, or leisure activities because of your headaches?

What your Physician will need to know about your headaches:
  1. How many days in the last 3 months did you have a headache? (If a headache lasted more than one day, count each day.)
  2. On a scale of 0–10, on average how painful were these headaches? (Where 0 = no pain at all, and 10 = pain as bad as it can be.)

Grading

Total MIDAS scores categorize migraine-related disability into four grades:

  • Grade I: Little or no disability (0–5)
  • Grade II: Mild disability (6–10)
  • Grade III: Moderate disability (11–20)
  • Grade IV: Severe disability (≥ 21)

 

To determine the specific medication needed for treatment (Option A): The MIDAS questionnaire does not focus on identifying specific medications; it is designed to assess the impact of migraines on a person's life, not to prescribe treatment.

 

To assess the frequency of headache attacks (Option B): While the MIDAS includes questions related to headache frequency, its primary aim is to evaluate the disability and limitations caused by the headaches rather than simply counting their occurrence.

 

To classify the type of headache (Option D): The MIDAS does not classify the type of headache. Its focus is on assessing the impact of headaches on daily functioning rather than diagnosing or categorizing the headaches themselves.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese NRI woman presents to her doctor with a history of frequent migraines. She reports experiencing about ten migraine attacks per month. Her father is a diabetic and underwent CABG recently. She says due to ill health of her father her symptoms tend to last upto 24 hours. Her recent lipid profile is deranged. Which of the following preventive treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fremanezumab

Explanation:

The patient has frequent migraine attacks, experiencing > five per month, which qualifies her for preventive treatment according to clinical guidelines.Fremanezumab once a month is suitable for this patient due to following reasons- 

  1. Highly effective in frequent migraines

  2. No metabolic side effects: Weight-neutral, lipid-neutral, glucose-neutral. This patient has deranged lipids, has obesity and has family history of both diabetes mellitus and heart disease. 

  3. Once-monthly injection = high compliance . only limitation is high cost 

  4. Can be used safely in patients with metabolic syndrome, obesity, or diabetes risk.

Treatment of Acute Migraine

Prevention of Migraine
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Simple Analgesics: Acetaminophen, aspirin, caffeine. (Option A ruled out)
    • NSAIDs: Naproxen, ibuprofen, tolfenamic acid, diclofenac.
    • Triptans (5-HT1B/1D Agonists): Sumatriptan, rizatriptan, naratriptan, eletriptan, frovatriptan, zolmitriptan. (Option C ruled out)
    • Gepants (CGRP Receptor Antagonists): Rimegepant, ubrogepant. (Option D ruled out)
    • Ditans (5-HT1F Agonists): Lasmiditan.
    • Dopamine Receptor Antagonists: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine.
    • Other Options: Combination medications (e.g., acetaminophen, dichloralphenazone, isometheptene), opioids (limited use).
  • Non-Pharmacologic Management:
    • Identify and avoid triggers.
    • Regulated lifestyle: Healthy diet, regular exercise, consistent sleep, stress management (e.g., yoga, meditation).
    • Neuromodulation techniques: sTMS, nVNS.
  • Key Recommendations:
    • Use medications early in an attack.
    • If symptoms persist after 60 minutes, consider increasing the initial dose or switching drug classes.
    • Individualize treatment based on attack severity and patient response.
  • Indications for Preventive Treatment:
    • Consider for patients with four or more migraine attacks per month or those unresponsive to abortive treatments.
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Beta Blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol.
    • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, venlafaxine.
    • Anticonvulsants: Topiramate, valproate.
    • CGRP Antagonists: Eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab.
    • Other Medications: Flunarizine, candesartan, melatonin.
  • Considerations:
    • Preventive treatments often take 2–12 weeks to show effect.
    • Side effects vary; some medications require careful monitoring (e.g., weight gain with certain antidepressants).
    • Neuromodulation (sTMS) is also FDA-approved for prevention.
  • Patient Management:
    • Start with low doses and gradually increase.
    • Monitor effectiveness and side effects.
    • After stabilization, taper off medication after approximately six months to assess ongoing need.

Severity Classification

Migraine severity can be assessed using tools like the Migraine Disability Assessment Scale (MIDAS), which categorizes migraines as follows:

  • Grade 1: Little or no disability
  • Grade 2: Mild disability
  • Grade 3: Moderate disability
  • Grade 4: Serious disability

Acute Treatment (Abortive Therapy)

  1. Mild to Moderate Migraine (Grade 1-2)
    • Over-the-Counter Pain Relievers:Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen.
    • Triptans: Medications like sumatriptan or rizatriptan are effective for moderate migraines and should be taken at the onset of symptoms.
  2. Moderate to Severe Migraine (Grade 3-4)
    • Triptans: Higher doses or different formulations (e.g., nasal sprays, injections) may be necessary.
    • Dihydroergotamine: Effective for longer-lasting migraines; available as a nasal spray or injection.
    • Gepants: Ubrogepant and rimegepant are newer oral medications that can relieve pain and associated symptoms like nausea.
    • Lasmiditan: An oral medication that can help with pain relief but may cause sedation.
  3. Status Migrainosus (Severe, prolonged attacks lasting over 72 hours)
    • Requires immediate medical attention.
    • Treatment may include intravenous fluids, anti-nausea medications, and possibly corticosteroids or stronger analgesics in a hospital setting.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ER after collapsing at a rave party. His friends report that he had been dancing intensely and suddenly developed a severe headache followed by a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. On arrival, he is unconscious with a BP of 180/100 mmHg. NCCT brain shows an hyperdensity in the basal ganglia region. Urine toxicology screen is positive for benzoylecgonine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his presentation?

choices.text: Acute hypertensive crisis due to pheochromocytoma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C:Cocaine-induced vasospasm and hypertension

Explanation:

  • Cocaine causes sympathetic overdrive by inhibiting reuptake of catecholamines (dopamine, norepinephrine).

  • This leads to acute hypertension, cerebral vasospasm, and predisposes to CNS hemorrhage, especially in young individuals with no vascular risk factors.

  • Benzoylecgonine in urine confirms recent cocaine use (it is the major non-psychoactive metabolite).

  • Aneurysm rupture is more common in older adults with subarachnoid pattern; serotonin syndrome usually presents with autonomic instability + hyperreflexia, not hemorrhage.

  • Serotonin syndrome has tremors, muscle rigidity, muscle spasms, overactive reflexes, and myoclonus with autonomic features and is close option. Urine toxicology report seals the answer as option C

questions.text: Which of the following types of headaches is not classified as a primary headache?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Medication overuse headache

Explanation:

Medication overuse headache is classified as a secondary headache because it results from the frequent use of headache medication including opoids. Tension-type headaches, migraines, and primary stabbing headaches are all considered primary headaches.

Primary Headaches

Secondary Headaches
  • Migraine (with or without aura) (Option C ruled out)
  • Tension-type headache- Most common (Option A ruled out)
  • Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (cluster) (Option D ruled out)
  • Primary stabbing headache
  • Primary coughing headache
  • Primary exertional headache
  • Sex-related headache
  • Thunderclap headache
  • New daily persistent headache syndrome
  • Medication overuse headache (chronic daily headache)
  • Intracranial bleeding (subdural haematoma, subarachnoid or intracerebral haemorrhage)
  • Raised intracranial pressure (brain tumour, idiopathic intracranial hypertension)
  • Infection (meningitis, encephalitis, brain abscess)
  • Inflammatory disease (temporal arteritis, other vasculitis, arthritis)
  • Referred pain from other structures (orbit, temporomandibular joint, neck)

Extra mile 

Features of a dangerous headache:

  • Stiff neck
  • Rash
  • The worst headache you’ve ever had
  • Vomiting
  • Confusion
  • Slurred speech
  • Fever of 100.4°F (38°C) or higher
  • Paralysis in any part of your body
  • Visual loss

questions.text: A newborn delivered by forceps has a high-pitched cry and bulging anterior fontanelle. The mother notes that the baby seems unusually irritable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step and management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) USG skull and phenobarbitone

Explanation:

  • The newborn has signs suggestive of intracranial hemorrhage, likely due to birth trauma (forceps delivery). The high-pitched cry, bulging anterior fontanelle, and irritability are concerning for increased intracranial pressure (ICP), potentially due to subdural or epidural hemorrhage.
  • CT scan of the head is the initial diagnostic imaging of choice for detecting intracranial hemorrhage in neonates, especially in emergency situations.

Intraventricular Hemorrhage in Neonates

Key Risk Factors

- Prematurity (≤32 weeks)

- Low birth weight (<1500g)

- No antenatal steroids

- Vaginal delivery

Clinical Features

- Bulging fontanelle

- Apnea/lethargy

- Seizures

- Often asymptomatic

Diagnosis

- Head USG (primary tool)

- MRI for complications

Management

- Minimal handling

- Maintain stable BP

- Monitor for hydrocephalus

- Phenobarbital for convulsion prevention

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with atrial fibrillation on warfarin presents with progressive confusion and unsteady gait over the past month. His wife reports he had a minor fall 6 weeks ago. On examination, he is confused, has mild right sided weakness. NCCT brain is given below. Which of the following is correct about this patient?

choices.text: Arterial bleeding with craniotomy and ligation of bleeder
Venous bleeding with burr hole surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Venous bleeding with burr hole surgery

Explanation:
This case presents classic features of chronic subdural hematoma due to following reasons:

  1. Risk factors: elderly, anticoagulation, brain atrophy, minor trauma 
  2. Gradual symptom progression over weeks ( came at one month) 
  3. Nonspecific symptoms: confusion, gait issues, mild weakness
  4. left sided concavo hyperdensity with islands of hypodensity due to resorbtion of blood 
  5. Hence patient will require a Burr hole surgery . It will help in evacutation of liquified hematoma 

 

Acute SDH vs Chronic SDH:

Feature

Acute SDH

Chronic SDH

Timing

0-72 hours

>3 weeks

Clinical Features

- Rapid deterioration

- Loss of consciousness

- Focal deficits

- High mortality

- Gradual onset

- Confusion

- Headache

- Gait disturbance

- Better prognosis

Risk Factors

- Severe trauma

- Young adults

- Coagulopathy

- Elderly

- Brain atrophy

- Anticoagulation

- Minor trauma

CT Findings

- Hyperdense crescent

- Immediate mass effect

- Hypodense/mixed density

- Bilateral in 20-30%

- Gradual mass effect

Management

- Emergency craniotomy

- Reverse coagulopathy

- ICU care

- Burr hole drainage

- Hold anticoagulation

- May observe small ones

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck in the temporal region during a hockey game. Initially conscious at the scene, he now presents with decreasing consciousness, right-sided pupillary dilation, and left hemiparesis. CT head shows a lentiform hyperdense lesion in the right temporal region with 12mm midline shift. Which of the following is most appropriate treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Mannitol followed by Burr hole surgery
Burr hole followed by craniotomy and ligation of bleeder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Burr hole followed by craniotomy and ligation of bleeder

Explanation:
This case presents a classic epidural hematoma requiring emergency intervention because of:

  1. Deteriorating consciousness
  2. Focal neurological signs (pupillary dilation, hemiparesis)
  3. Significant midline shift (>5mm)
  4. Classic temporal location suggesting middle meningeal artery involvement

Other indications of Evacuation:

  • Clot >30cc vol
  • Thickness>1.5 mm
  • GCS<9

Extradural hematomas are neurosurgical emergencies when symptomatic.

  • Emergency- Burr hole surgery
  • Definitive- Craniotomy with hematoma evacuation.

Clinical Features of Epidural Hematoma (EDH)

  1. Initial Loss of Consciousness: Often after trauma, followed by a brief lucid interval (temporary recovery of consciousness), which occurs in 14% to 21% of EDH cases. However, not all patients experience a lucid interval.
  2. Neurological Deterioration: The lucid interval may end with rapid neurological deterioration as the hematoma expands and raises intracranial pressure (ICP).
  3. Variable Consciousness Levels: Some patients may not experience a lucid interval, with presentations ranging from initial unconsciousness to coma.
  4. Posterior Fossa EDH: Rare but severe, accounting for about 5% of EDH cases. Delayed loss of consciousness can occur as the hematoma grows, and patients may become apneic and die if untreated.
  5. Signs of Elevated ICP: As the hematoma enlarges, ipsilateral pupil dilation (due to uncal herniation and oculomotor nerve compression) can occur, along with elevated blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular breathing (known as the Cushing reflex).

 

Observe and monitor neurological status (Option A): Incorrect because observation alone is dangerous in a deteriorating patient with significant mass effect.

 

Start mannitol and hyperventilate (Option B): Incorrect because while these measures may temporarily help, they are adjuncts to definitive surgical management.

 

Conservative management with anticonvulsants (Option D): Incorrect because conservative management is inappropriate for a large, symptomatic extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man on warfarin (INR 2.5) falls and hits his head. He is initially alert and oriented, but after 2 hours, becomes progressively drowsy and confused. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epidural hematoma

Explanation:
This case presents the classic scenario of an epidural hematoma as suggested by presence of lucid interval and CT showing characteristic biconvex (lentiform) hyperdense lesion.

A lucid interval (LI) refers to a brief period of normal consciousness following an initial loss of consciousness, often seen in cerebral concussion or cerebral compression. In cases like epidural hematoma, the lucid interval occurs as the brain temporarily recovers before increased pressure from the hematoma leads to further deterioration.

Lucid Interval and its Causes:

Type

Lucid Interval

CT Findings

Mechanism

Epidural Hematoma

++

- Biconvex/lentiform shape

- Does not cross suture lines

- Cross dural venous sinuses

- Hyperdense

- Usually unilateral

-Typically meningeal artery injury (especially middle meningeal)

-High velocity trauma

-Young patient

-Always traumatic

Subdural Hematoma (Option B)

+/-

- Crescent-shaped

- Crosses suture lines

- Can be bilateral

- Don't cross dural venous sinuses

- Follows brain surface

- Bridging vein tears

- Can be Traumatic or non traumatic

- Elderly patients

- Extent of brain injury more in SDH than EDH

Intraparenchymal Hematoma (Option C)

Absent

- Irregular shape within brain tissue

- May have surrounding edema

Direct tissue damage or coagulopathy

Subarachnoid Haemorrhage       (Option D)

Absent

- Blood in sulci/cisterns

- Follows CSF spaces

Trauma or aneurysm rupture

Other causes of lucid Interval:

  • Melancholia (Major Depressive Disorder)
  • Insanity (Psychiatric Disorders)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Seizures (Postictal State)
  • Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with headache, left sided face arm and leg weakness. His sensorium is fast deteriorating and he is known case of  rheumatic heart disease on  warfarin. His INR is 10. NCCT head is given below. Which of the following is correct about his management?

choices.text: Fast infusion of fresh frozen plasma
Fast infusion of fresh frozen plasma and urgent neurosurgery
4-factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate and Vitamin K 10mg IV

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4-factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate  and  Vitamin K 10mg IV

Explanation:
This patient presents with classic features of warfarin-associated intracranial hemorrhage:

  1. Patient is on warfarin therapy
  2. Supratherapeutic INR 10.0 
  3. Acute neurological symptoms (headache, weakness, altered mental status)
  4. Confirmed intraparenchymal hemorrhage on CT

This represents a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate reversal of anticoagulation by 4-factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC) & Vitamin K 10mg IV. Tranexamic acid may also be considered.

Warfarin associated Intracranial Hemorrhage- Management

First-line Treatment

4-factor PCC

- Rapid INR reversal

- Contains factors II, VII, IX, X

- Faster than FFP

- Lower volume load

Second Component

Vitamin K 10mg IV

- Sustains reversal

- Prevents rebound coagulopathy

- Takes hours for full effect

Additional Treatment

Tranexamic acid

- Antifibrinolytic

- May help stabilize hemorrhage

Alternative if PCC unavailable

FFP (15-30 mL/kg)

- Restores clotting factors to 30-50%

- Requires larger volumes

- Slower to administer

Management Strategies Based on INR Levels

Without Significant Bleeding

  • INR <4.5: No immediate intervention unless there are other risk factors.
  • INR 4.5 - 10: Administer oral vitamin K (1-2 mg) if there are no signs of bleeding; monitor INR closely.
  • INR >10: Administer oral vitamin K (5-10 mg) and monitor INR closely; consider hospitalization if the patient has risk factors for bleeding.

With Significant Bleeding

  • Life-threatening Bleeding:
    • Discontinue warfarin immediately.
    • Administer intravenous vitamin K (5-10 mg) and prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) depending on availability.
  • Clinically Significant Bleeding:
    • Similar to life-threatening situations, but with careful monitoring and possibly lower doses of PCC or FFP based on clinical judgment

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive man suddenly develops facial asymetry and right arm weakness during a meeting. His BP on arrival  is 220/130 mmHg. CT shows putaminal hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Nicardipine to achieve target BP of 140/90 mm Hg or lesser
Sodium nitroprusside to achieve target BP of 140/90 mm Hg or lesser

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IV Nicardipine to achieve a target BP of 140/90 mm Hg 

Explanation:

Nicardipine is recommended as a first-line agent in the acute management of hemorrhagic stroke to reduce elevated blood pressure. According to the latest guidelines, blood pressure should be rapidly but safely lowered to a target of <140/90 mm Hg, as this has been shown to reduce the risk of rebleeding without increasing the risk of ischemia.

Earlier guidelines advocated a more gradual reduction in blood pressure, but recent evidence supports early intensive control for better outcomes.

Sodium nitroprusside is not preferred due to its tendency to cause a rapid and uncontrolled drop in blood pressure, which can lead to cerebral hypoperfusion and infarction, especially in patients with impaired cerebral autoregulation during hypertensive crises.

Mannitol is generally contraindicated in active CNS bleeding unless there is evidence of raised intracranial pressure with herniation risk, as it may worsen bleeding by altering intracranial hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive male presents with sudden onset weakness of right face and arm, along with difficulty speaking. He is unable to form words properly but appears to understand commands. Brain imaging shows an acute infarct. Which division of the MCA is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Superior division of left MCA

Explanation:

The combination of:

  • Right facial weakness
  • Right arm weakness
  • Non-fluent (Broca's) aphasia
  • Preserved comprehension

This pattern suggests a superior division MCA stroke in the dominant (left) hemisphere, affecting the frontal opercular region and motor cortex.

MCA Syndromes:

MCA territory strokes present differently based on the involved segment:

Inferior division of left MCA (Option B)

  • This typically presents with:
  • Wernicke's (fluent) aphasia
  • Poor comprehension
  • Jargon speech
  • Superior quadrantanopia
  • Usually no significant motor deficits

Main trunk of left MCA (Option C)

  • Would cause a complete MCA syndrome
  • More extensive deficits involving both superior and inferior division territories
  • More severe motor deficits including face, arm, and leg-Complete hemiparesis
  • Both expressive and receptive language deficits-Global aphasia (if dominant hemisphere)
  • Hemisensory loss
  • Hemianopia

Lenticulostriate branches of left MCA (Option D)

  • Causes lacunar syndromes
  • Pure motor stroke or sensory-motor stroke
  • Affects internal capsule
  • No cortical symptoms like aphasia
  • Affects internal capsule

questions.text: An 82-year-old normotensive, non-diabetic man presents with sudden onset confusion and headache. MRI shows multiple lobar hemorrhages. Which is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cerebral amyloid angiopathy

Explanation:

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy fits the characteristic features of this patient:

  • Elderly patient (>60 years)
  • No history of hypertension
  • Multiple lobar hemorrhages in MRI
  • Acute neurological presentation

CAA- Imaging characteristics:

  • Multiple lobar hemorrhages
  • Cortical-subcortical location
  • Microbleeds on gradient echo MRI
  • Spares deep structures

Management implications:

  • Avoid anticoagulation
  • Careful with antiplatelets
  • Monitor for clinical deterioration
  • Regular neurological follow-up

Risk factors:

  • Advanced age
  • Genetic predisposition-APOE ε2 and ε4 alleles
  • Associated with dementia
  • No direct relation to hypertension

Feature

Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA)    (Option A)

Berry Aneurysm Rupture   (Option B ruled out)

Hypertensive Crisis     (Option C ruled out)

Venous Sinus Thrombosis (Option D ruled out)

Age Group

Elderly (>60 years)

Younger

Older, with chronic HTN

Younger, hypercoagulable states

Hypertension

None

None

Chronic HTN

None

Hemorrhage Type

Multiple lobar hemorrhages

Subarachnoid, single event

Deep (e.g., putamen, thalamus)

Hemorrhagic infarction

Hemorrhage Location

Cortical-subcortical regions

Subarachnoid space

Deep brain structures

Venous infarction

Imaging

Lobar hemorrhages, microbleeds

Single, subarachnoid bleed

Deep hemorrhage

Venous infarction pattern

Symptoms

Acute neurological symptoms

Thunderclap headache

Often no symptoms

Seizures, focal deficits

Onset

Acute neurological presentation

Sudden, thunderclap headache

Acute, with chronic HTN

Acute, gradual progression

Distribution

Spares deep structures

Focal

Deep brain

Venous infarction
